questions.text: The patient came with a complaint of Trichomonas (features) vaginalis. Select which is the correct statement with respect to it.

options.label: C
options.text: Seen only in an immunocompromised patient

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trichomonas has twitching motility

Highyeild:

Bacterial vaginosis signs and symptoms may include: Thin, grey, white, or green vaginal discharge Foul-smelling "fishy" vaginal odour Vaginal itching Burning during urination The clinical criteria for diagnosing Bacterial vaginosis is the presence of three of Amsel's criteria: pH≥4.5, positive whiff test, gr eyish-white homogeneous vaginal discharge, and presence of clue cells . Treatment is with Tab Metronidazole 200mg TID x 7 days.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false. It is caused by an imbalance of the vaginal flora.

Extraedge:

In the management of Bacterial Vaginosis and Trichomonas vaginalis Kit 2 (Green), Secnidazole 2 gm stat can also be used. 20% clue cells must be present to diagnose Bacterial Vaginosis

questions.text: A female with multiple sexual partners came with a complaint of fever. On examination swelling of labia majora was seen which was tender and red. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bartholin abscess The Bartholin’s glands are situated at 5 and 7'o clock positions between the hymen and labia minora. Infection of a Bartholin’s cyst leads to an abscess formation. The treatment of choice for symptomatic cysts is marsupialization.

Highyeild:

The Bartholin’s glands are situated at 5 and 7'o clock positions between the hymen and labia minora. Infection of a Bartholin’s cyst leads to an abscess formation. The treatment of choice for symptomatic cysts is marsupialization.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false and are usually accompanied by vaginal discharge and itching. Fever and swelling of labia majora points to a diagnosis of Bartholin’s abscess.

Extraedge:

The criteria used for the diagnosis of Bartholin gland cancer is known as the Honan criteria.

questions.text: A lady who is 38 weeks pregnant comes to the OPD for a routine checkup. She has a history of normal twin delivery at term 4 years ago. What is her gravida and para score?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

G2P1

Highyeild:

Gravidity is defined as the number of times that a woman has been pregnant. Parity is defined as the number of times that she has given birth to a fetus with a gestational age of 24 weeks or more , regardless of whether the child was born alive or was stillborn. For example, a woman who is described as 'gravida 2, para 2 (sometimes abbreviated to G2 P2) has had two pregnancies and two deliveries after 24 weeks, and a woman who is described as 'gravida 2, para 0' (G2 P0) has had two pregnancies, neither of which survived to a gestational age of 24 weeks. If they are both currently pregnant again, these women would have an obstetric history of G3 P2 and G3 P0 respectively. Sometimes a suffix is added to indicate the number of miscarriages or terminations a woman has had. So if the second woman had had two miscarriages, it could be annotated G3 P0+2. A nulliparous woman (nullip) has not given birth previously (regardless of outcome). A primigravida is in her first pregnancy. A primiparous woman has given birth once. A multigravida has been pregnant more than once. A multiparous woman (multip) has given birth more than once.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false.

Extraedge:

A grand multipara is a woman who has already delivered five or more infants who have achieved a gestational age of 24 weeks or more, and such women are traditionally considered to be at higher risk than the average in subsequent pregnancies. A grand multigravida has been pregnant five times or more. A great grand multipara has delivered seven or more infants beyond 24 weeks of gestation. A more elaborate coding system used is GTPAL (G = gravidity, T = term deliveries, P = preterm deliveries, A = abortions or miscarriages, L = live births).

questions.text: A 24-year pregnant woman came for an antenatal check-up. Her Hb is 9.4. What will you advise her, she is currently 9 weeks pregnant.
questions.correct_answer: A. Take iron tablets from now
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Take iron tablets from now Iron tablets must be started as soon as anemia is diagnosed. Anaemia: Hb 11 gm%, Severe Anemia: Hb 7 gm%, Very Severe Anemia 4 gm% The most common cause of anaemia in pregnancy is physiological anemia. The most common pathological cause is iron deficiency. The most common type is dimorphic anaemia. The most sensitive marker is serum ferritin. The management: 2-3 tabs/day followed by 1 tab/day for 180 days post delivery.

Highyeild:

Anaemia: Hb 11 gm%, Severe Anemia: Hb 7 gm%, Very Severe Anemia 4 gm% The most common cause of anaemia in pregnancy is physiological anemia. The most common pathological cause is iron deficiency. The most common type is dimorphic anaemia. The most sensitive marker is serum ferritin. The management: 2-3 tabs/day followed by 1 tab/day for 180 days post delivery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false.

Extraedge:

Blood transfusion indications: If during labour, Hb < 7gm% Bleeding leading to Hb < 6gm% Heart failure with decreased Hb < 34 weeks + Hb < 5 gm% >34 weeks + Hb < 7gm%

questions.text: Patient with 32 wks pregnancy with difficulty in breathing and respiration. Abdominal distension but no tenderness. Fetal parts are not palpable. Fetal movements are normal. Symphysis fundal height is 41cm. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Polyhydramnios Fetal parts not palpable, respiratory distress and an increase in fundal height point towards a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

Highyeild:

Causes of polyhydramnios: Diabetes in pregnancy Fetal anaemia Twins Intrauterine infections Trisomy 18, 21 GIT, NTD, Abdominal wall defects

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false.

Extraedge:

Important associations of polyhydramnios: Respiratory distress PROM Abruption Preterm labour Malpresentations Cord prolapse Amniotic fluid embolism

questions.text: A pregnant female complains of dizziness on lying down but relief on sitting up or lying lateral. Why?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vena caval compression

Highyeild:

Cardiac output is lowest in the supine position because of IVC compression. This can lead to fatigue and dizziness. Therefore left lateral position is advised. CO is highest in the immediate postpartum period. Systemic vascular resistance declines by 30%. This enhances uteroplacental perfusion. Diastolic and systolic blood pressure decreases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false. As dizziness is relieved on sitting up or lying lateral it is most likely due to IVC compression.

Extraedge:

JVP and EF remain normal. ECG - Left axis deviation Loud S1 with splitting

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient came with her mother with the complaint of primary amenorrhea on physical examination. It was revealed that breasts were present, but no pubic hair. On the TVS uterus, FT ovaries were not seen. Inguinal region swelling is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis of the patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

AIS Absent pubic hair which is under the influence of testosterone, presence of breasts and primary amenorrhea point towards a diagnosis of AIS.

Highyeild:

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) is a common aetiology of sexual developmental disorders resulting in varying phenotypes. These disorders of androgen action present as 46 XY disorders or differences of sex development (DSD). The phenotypic spectrum of AIS depends on the residual androgen receptor activity and encompasses individuals with a completely female phenotype to male phenotype with infertility/undervirilization .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false. Features of Turner syndrome may include short stature, short neck with a webbed appearance , low hairline at the back of the neck, low-set ears , hands and feet that are swollen or puffy at birth, and soft nails that turn upward. In Turner syndrome, ovarian failure and reduced ovarian feedback result in significantly elevated FSH and LH levels whereas gonadotropin levels are not significantly elevated. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome , also referred to as Müllerian aplasia, is a congenital disorder characterised by aplasia of the uterus and upper part of the vagina in females with normal secondary sex characteristics and a normal female karyotype (46, XX).

questions.text: A 23 yr old female undergoing treatment for infertility with IVF was given Inj. HMG presents with a history of vomiting, nausea and headache. The USG is shown below, what is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome The patient came with the complaint of abdominal distention and vomiting and USG also shows multiple cysts of varying sizes, giving the classic spoke-wheel appearance. This is a typical case of OHSS.

Highyeild:

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a medical condition that can occur in some women who take fertility medication to stimulate egg growth and in other women in very rare cases. Most cases are mild, but rarely the condition is severe and can lead to serious illness or death. Symptoms: Pain, abdominal distention, nausea, and vomiting.

Extraedge:

Classification: Based on the clinical manifestation and imaging findings, the modified Golan classification divides OHSS into the following three categories with 5 grades. Mild OHSS : Characterized by bilateral multicystic ovarian enlargement. Grade 1: Abdominal distention and discomfort. Grade 2: Plus nausea, vomiting and/or diarrhoea plus ovarian enlargement from 5 to 12 cm. Moderate OHSS : If there is associated ascites and abdominal distension. Grade 3: Features of mild OHSS plus ultrasonographic evidence of Ascites. Severe OHSS : Characterized by hypovolemia, haemoconcentration, thrombosis, oliguria, pleural and pericardial effusion Grade 4: Moderate OHSS plus clinical evidence of ascites and/or hydrothorax and dyspnea Grade 5: Grade 4 plus the change in blood volume, hemoconcentration, coagulation abnormalities and diminished kidney perfusion and function

questions.text: Primigravida with UPT positive & HCG 2800, 6 weeks amenorrhea. Palpable mass on the left side. On USG fetal cardiac activity is absent. Vitals are stable. What is the appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inj. MTX

Highyeild:

Selection of an appropriate candidate for medical management of ectopic pregnancy: Contraindications Good Candidate Poor Candidate ● Hemodynamically unstable ● Suspected ruptured EP ● Sensitivity to MTX ● Intrauterine pregnancy ● Breastfeeding ● Active pulmonary disease ● Renal disease ● Chronic liver disease ● Pre-existing blood dyscrasia ● Immunodeficiency ● Peptic ulcer disease ● Unable to comply with visits and follow-up ● Hemodynamically stable ● Low hCG (< 5000 mIU/ml) ● Small mass (<3.5 cm) ● Unruptured mass ● No embryonic cardiac activity ● The certainty that there is no IUP ● Willingness for follow-up ● No known sensitivity to MTX ● High hCG (>5000 mIU/ml) ● Large mass (>3.5 cm) ● Embryonic cardiac activity present ● Significant abdominal pain ● IUP has been ruled out ● Questionable ability to return for all outpatient visits

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents at 36 wks + 6 days gestation. On examination, the fetus was transverse with adequate liquor, the placenta was in a normal position. The weight of the baby is 2.8 kg. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

External cephalic version ECV is done at 37 weeks if there are no contraindications. The incidence of breech presentation is maximum at 28 weeks. Do ECV at 37 weeks if there are no contraindications. If ECV is contraindicated then the preferred mode of delivery is C-section.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false.

questions.text: Anxious mother-in-law comes with daughter-in-law after 6 months of marriage and cohabitation. They have been trying for 6 months to give her a grandchild. What do you advise?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reassurance & come after 6 months. This option is correct since they haven't had unprotected intercourse since one year.

Highyeild:

Infertility is defined as the inability to achieve pregnancy with frequent and unprotected sexual intercourse for 1 year if a woman is less than 35 years or 6 months if a woman is more than 35 years. Primary hypogonadism is the most common cause of male factor infertility. Management: If the count is less than 15 million/mL then do IUI. If count less than 10 million/mL then do IVF. If count less than 5 million then do ICSI.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false.

Extraedge:

Asthenospermia refers to decreased motility of sperm. Azoospermia refers to no sperm in the ejaculate. Test to differentiate between obstructive and non-obstructive azoospermia: FSH > LH & testosterone.

questions.text: When is iron given to an anaemic pregnant female?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

14 weeks

Highyeild:

Anemia: Hb 11 gm%, Severe Anemia: Hb 7 gm%, Very Severe Anemia 4 gm% Most common cause of anaemia in pregnancy is physiological anaemia. Most common pathological cause is iron deficiency. Most common type is dimorphic anaemia. Most sensitive marker is serum ferritin. Management: 2-3 tabs/day followed by 1 tab/day for 180 days post delivery.

Extraedge:

Blood transfusion indications: If during labour, Hb < 7gm% Bleeding leading to Hb < 6gm% Heart failure with decreased Hb < 34 weeks + Hb < 5 gm% >34 weeks + Hb < 7gm%

questions.text: Female with lower abdominal pain for one month, history of multiple sexual partners, mild intermenstrual bleeding, scanty vaginal discharge and dysuria which subsided on its own. The most likely causative organism is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gonorrhea Gonorrhoea is the most common cause of acute PID. Since the female has h/o multiple sexual partners the answer is Gonorrhea.

Highyeild:

Most common PID due to IUCD: Actinomyces Most common PID in virgin females: Genital TB. Most common route of spread of PID: Ascending infection except genital TB which is spread by a hematogenous route.

Extraedge:

Prognostic scoring for conception in the case of PID can be done using Boer Miesel Score.

questions.text: A 16-year-old young female with primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain in the abdomen, on physical examination has a suprapubic bulge and on P/R examination there's swelling along the whole length of the vagina. What is the diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Transverse vaginal septum in the upper ⅓ of vagina

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Imperforate Hymen Imperforate hymen is the most common cause of cryptomenorrhea.

Highyeild:

Cryptomenorrhea is a condition in which menstruation occurs but is not visible due to obstruction of the outflow tract resulting in either hematometra (blood collection within the uterus) or hematocolpos (blood collection within the vagina). Causes: Primary: Cervical atresia Vaginal aplasia Transverse vaginal septum Imperforate hymen Secondary Cervical Cauterization Cervical conization (Leep diathermy)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - A transverse vaginal septum is a horizontal "wall" of tissue that has formed during embryologic development and essentially creates a blockage of the vagina. It can occur at many different levels of the vagina. When the septum is completely blocking the upper vagina from the lower vagina, menstrual blood will pool in the upper vagina, which causes cyclical abdominal pain.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl's mother had a history of cervical cancer and she was operated on, for the same. What advice would you give to the girl?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HPV Vaccine HPV vaccination is recommended at ages 11–12 years. HPV vaccines can be given starting at age 9 years. All preteens need HPV vaccination, so they are protected from HPV infections that can cause cancer later in life. Teens and young adults through age 26 years who didn’t start or finish the HPV vaccine series also need HPV vaccination.

Highyeild:

Cervical cancer is the most common gynaecological malignancy in the world . Most common age group - the bimodal peak - 1st peak seen at 35-39 years and 2nd peak 60-56 years. The most specific symptom is postcoital bleeding. Histologic reevaluation of cervical biopsy is the primary tool to diagnose cervical cancer . PAP smears are performed extensively to screen for this cancer but this test does not always detect cervical cancer. It has only 50-80 % for detecting high-grade lesions. Therefore, these lesions are directly biopsied, and biopsy is taken from the tumour periphery, as central portions often contain only necrotic tissue which fails to yield a diagnosis.

Extraedge:

Dose schedule as per WHO: <21 years - 1 or 2 doses. >21 years - 2 doses 6 months apart. Screening for cervical cancer is started at 21 years with PAP every 3 years or HPV DNA testing every 5 years.

questions.text: A female gives a history of multiple sexual partners and is diagnosed with cervical cancer extending to the left parametrium with lateral wall involvement. What treatment option would you suggest?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chemo-radiation In the given question, the stage is B. Therefore chemoradiation is done.

Highyeild:

Cervical cancer is the most common gynaecological malignancy in the world . Most common age group - bimodal peak - 1st peak is seen at 35-39 years and 2nd peak 60-56 years. The most specific symptom is postcoital bleeding. Histologic reevaluation of cervical biopsy is the primary tool to diagnose cervical cancer . PAP smears are performed extensively to screen for this cancer but this test does not always detect cervical cancer. It has only 50-80 % for detecting high-grade lesions. Therefore, these lesions are directly biopsied, and biopsy is taken from the tumour periphery, as central portions often contain only necrotic tissue which fails to yield a diagnosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and C are false.

Extraedge:

Stage 1 means that the cancer is only in the neck of the womb (cervix). Surgery is the main treatment. Some people need chemoradiotherapy too. Stage 2 means the cancer has spread outside the cervix, into the surrounding tissues. The main treatments are a combination of chemotherapy and radiotherapy (chemoradiotherapy) and sometimes surgery. Stage 3 means the cancer has spread from the cervix into the structures around it or into the lymph nodes in the pelvis or abdomen. Treatment is usually a combination of chemotherapy and radiotherapy (chemoradiotherapy). Stage 4 means the cancer has spread to the bladder or back passage (rectum) or further away. The main treatments are chemotherapy with a targeted cancer drug, surgery, radiotherapy or symptom control.

questions.text: In cancer cervix, neoadjuvant therapy is given?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Before radical surgery

Highyeild:

Treatment given as a first step to shrink a tumour before the main treatment, which is usually surgery, is given. Examples of neoadjuvant therapy include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. It is a type of induction therapy.

Extraedge:

Cervical cancer is the most common gynaecological malignancy in the world . Most common age group - bimodal peak - 1st peak is seen at 35-39 years and 2nd peak at 60-56 years. The most specific symptom is postcoital bleeding. Histologic reevaluation of cervical biopsy is the primary tool to diagnose cervical cancer . PAP smears are performed extensively to screen for this cancer but this test does not always detect cervical cancer. It has only 50-80 % for detecting high-grade lesions. Therefore, these lesions are directly biopsied, and biopsy is taken from the tumour periphery, as central portions often contain only necrotic tissue which fails to yield a diagnosis.
